title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — On a night when basketball history was written in the Minnesota night, Kevin Garnett didn't just beat the Boston Celtics; he authored a masterpiece, carrying the Timberwolves to a stunning 104-95 victory.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Garnett's stage. He was a force of nature, operating with a ferocious elegance that the Celtics, despite a valiant 26-point effort from Antoine Walker, had no answer for. Garnett’s 33 points were a career-high, but the stat sheet only tells half the story. It was the *how*—the relentless barrage of turnaround jumpers, powerful drives, and unyielding will—that left the Target Center crowd in a state of delirious awe.

While Walker and Rick Fox (18 points) tried to keep Boston afloat, the Celtics' attack was often disjointed, a stark contrast to the singular brilliance on the other side. Minnesota’s offense flowed through their young phenom, and he delivered with breathtaking consistency.

But Garnett’s legend wasn't forged on offense alone. He was a titan on both ends, snatching 15 rebounds and anchoring the defense. His complete dominance was the engine of the Wolves' victory, a one-man show that lifted his team to a crucial win against a storied franchise.

When the final horn sounded, the scoreboard told of a Minnesota win. But everyone in the building knew they had witnessed something far greater: the transcendent arrival of Kevin Garnett, a performance for the ages that announced a new king in the making.
